column1: What is the difference between food and nutrition?
column2: Food: plant and animal-based products we consume; provides chemicals for life. Nutrition: science that studies food and how it nourishes the body and health.

column1: What is the role of food in providing energy and supporting daily living?
column2: Food provides energy for activities, thinking, and immune function; supports daily living and social interactions.

column1: Name the six groups of nutrients found in foods.
column2: Carbohydrates, Fats and oils, Proteins, Vitamins, Minerals, Water

column1: What are the three macronutrients and how many kilocalories per gram do they provide?
column2: Carbohydrates: 4 kcal/g; Proteins: 4 kcal/g; Fats: 9 kcal/g

column1: What is a kilocalorie and why is it often referred to as a calorie on nutrition labels?
column2: Kilocalorie is the amount of heat to raise 1 kg of water by 1Â°C. Labels use calories to denote kilocalories.

column1: List the four most common diseases related to diet and lifestyle.
column2: Cardiovascular diseases (CVD), Cancers, Type 2 diabetes, Obesity

column1: Which foods are high in carbohydrates?
column2: Grains, fruits and vegetables, legumes, sugary foods and beverages

column1: Which foods provide fats?
column2: Butter, cream, oils, cold cuts, whole dairy products, ultra-processed foods

column1: Which foods provide proteins?
column2: Meats, fish, eggs, dairy, legumes and nuts, whole grains

column1: What are vitamins and minerals, and why are they essential for the body?
column2: Vitamins/Minerals: essential micronutrients needed for metabolism, growth, immune function, and health.

column1: Which vitamins are fat-soluble, and which are water-soluble?
column2: Fat-soluble: A, D, E, K. Water-soluble: C and B-vitamins

column1: Name two major minerals and two trace minerals.
column2: Major minerals: Calcium, Phosphorus (others include sodium, potassium, etc.). Trace minerals: Iron, Zinc (others include copper, manganese, selenium, iodine).

column1: What are the main functions of water in the body?
column2: Fluid balance, nerve impulses, temperature regulation, transport nutrients, excretion of waste.

column1: What are non-nutrient compounds found in foods, and give two examples?
column2: Non-nutrient compounds: Probiotics and Phytochemicals.

column1: What are probiotics, and what roles do they play in the gut?
column2: Beneficial bacteria that support gut health, digestion, immune function; present in yogurt, fermented foods.

column1: What are phytochemicals, name two classes, and one health role?
column2: Classes: Flavonoids, Carotenoids (examples). Role: antioxidant effects and cardiovascular protection.

column1: What are the three main steps of going from food to nutrients in the GI tract: digestion, absorption, and elimination?
column2: Digestion (breakdown), Absorption (nutrient uptake), Elimination (waste removal).

column1: What is the cephalic phase of digestion?
column2: First thought/anticipation of food; senses trigger GI preparation and digestive juice secretion.

column1: What are the roles of the mouth in digestion (mechanical and chemical)?
column2: Mechanical: chewing to break food; Chemical: saliva and salivary amylase begin carbohydrate digestion.

column1: What enzyme begins carbohydrate digestion in the mouth?
column2: Salivary amylase

column1: What is peristalsis and what does it accomplish in the esophagus?
column2: Rhythmic waves of muscle contractions that move the bolus toward the stomach.

column1: What is chyme and where is it formed?
column2: A semi-liquid mixture of partially digested food formed in the stomach.

column1: What are the roles of the stomach in digestion and what substances are absorbed there?
column2: Chemical digestion of proteins and lipids; some water, fluoride, lipids, and lipid-soluble drugs (e.g., aspirin, alcohol) are absorbed.

column1: What are the three sections of the small intestine and their primary roles?
column2: Duodenum, Jejunum, Ileum; major site of digestion and absorption.

column1: What are the roles of the liver, gallbladder, and pancreas in digestion?
column2: Liver produces bile; Gallbladder stores concentrate bile; Pancreas secretes digestive enzymes and hormones (insulin, glucagon).

column1: How are nutrients transported from the small intestine to the bloodstream and liver for water-soluble vs fat-soluble nutrients?
column2: Water-soluble nutrients: transported via blood to liver. Fat-soluble nutrients: transported via lymph (villi) to the bloodstream, then to the liver.

column1: What is the gut microbiome and what are two benefits to health?
column2: Communities of gut microbes; benefits include regulation of appetite/energy metabolism and immune support.

column1: What is intuitive eating and how does it relate to self-regulation in nutrition?
column2: Intuitive eating emphasizes listening to hunger/satiety cues and self-regulation in food choices.

column1: What is the energy molecule produced by cells and which organelle manufactures it?
column2: ATP produced by the mitochondrion.

column1: What is the difference between major minerals and trace minerals, and name two examples of each?
column2: Major minerals: required >100 mg/day (e.g., Calcium, Phosphorus). Trace minerals: <100 mg/day (e.g., Iron, Zinc).
